ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about different systems of government and regimes.
fundamentals of polysci.
Organizing short essays based on dense academic literature, learning about the political climate around us, and generating my own thoughts about ideal state structures.

I learned about various topics in this course including regime types, governments, elections / electoral systems, civil conflict, ethnic conflict, and more. I also learned a different way of effectively structuring an argumentative essay.
I learned how to read research papers and partially understand statistical analysis. I learned about governments inside and out, and I learned the skill on comparing and analyzing them.
Learned about the introductory concepts in comparative politics. (political participation, democratic backsliding, regime types etc)
knowledge and strong understanding on political systems, processes, and comparisons among different countries and regimes.

I acquired knowledge on the basic discipline of comparative politics, key themes, concepts, and studies. I also developed insight into how to adjudicate between various comparative politics frameworks and models, especially as they apply to specific circumstances. I practiced good writing skills for response and reflection papers, i.e. structuring an argument, considering counter-responses and offering defenses.
I learned more about democracies, autocracies, how to evaluate different regime types, and the history behind various regimes around the world.
Honestly, I have taken a lot of political science courses and did not learn much new theory. The readings and actual events I learned about were new.
Insights into state formation, regime structure and how that influences quality of life, types of regimes, types of democratic institutions and their influence, etc.
new terms about comparative politics, big political events in different countries, etc.

From this course, I was able to learn key aspects of government and politics (voting systems, civil conflicts, government structures, etc) and compare them between different countries internationally. I was encouraged to understand the differences between countries and evaluate the impact of these differences on quality of life or system efficiency.
What is democracy; what causes democracy to develop and decline

This course was very informative and similar to a public policy course I took at the London School of Economics over the summer. It combines a little bit of economic theory, political theory, and real-world examples to explain political movements across the world. Through the written responses I wrote during this class, I learned how to better research for a political science class, including how to incorporate data into a paper.
I learned some things from the textbook mainly. What was new knowledge for me was mostly information on political systems.
I learned a lot about the types of governments in different countries just by doing the minimum in discussion sections and for homework. Super interesting content with some great guest lectures!
More knowledge of how research methods and principles are applied in political science.
I learned a more world centric view to political institutions, their formation and management.

I developed the foundational knowledge required to understand different political systems across the world, specifically how they function, what defines them, how wars and outside things affect them, and so on. Through this course I also developed academic writing skills, especially utilizing data and primary sources within papers. Finally, in learning about different nations political systems so too was I able to develop some knowledge about cultures across the world.
Basic introduction to Comparative politics!
I learned some basic concepts surrounding the formation of the state, political violence, the definitions of regimes, and different electoral systems.
I learned note taking skills that specifically pertain to a large lecture based course.
I learned more about politics and political systems in general on a broad scale.

Taking Comparative Politics helped me understand the political structures and dynamics of countries other than the U.S. The course also introduced me to the vast literature of theories in comparative politics regarding a variety of topics like state formation, democratic backsliding, representation, and political participation to name a few. This course allowed me also to build on argumentation and analysis skills through assignments and section discussions and fostered a deeper curiosity for politics in general.
fascinating material. The lectures are basically the same as posted slides. It is unclear how she takes attendance on lectures. The assignments are weirdly worded.
By taking this course, I gained knowledge about central topics in comparative politics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A lot of the lectures felt super repetitive and boring. If the lectures were more interesting I would have had a more positive experience.
lots of material, sometimes too much.

Strengths - interesting content, light workload, short yet sometimes challenging assignments.
Weaknesses - sections sometimes felt disjointed from the lectures, we were often 2-3 lectures behind, lectures sometimes felt dry, readings were either fully discussed in lecture or kind of irrelevant, so you did not really have to do them.

The main strength of this course is its clarity, especially with regard to the assignments. I very much appreciated how clear Professor De La O was in her instructions. Although there were not any real weaknesses to this course, I wish we were able to spend a bit more time covering certain topics such as ethnic conflict.

I think the lectures were basic summaries of the readings, which made the readings feel very optional. If the lectures went beyond the readings, I feel like I would be more engaged. Also, I think the brunt of the difficulty comes at the beginning of the class, while the later units feel much easier. I think an opposite progression should take place. I think this course succeeds in distilling wide ranging topics in political science and making them feasible to look at in a class.

Its a great intro class in that the concepts and ideas are fairly simple, making it easier to do well and learn. I also liked that there were a lot of minor assignments through the semester, instead of having massive assignments at the end of the semester.

strength - discussion sections were very effective in preparation and greater understanding. and material was never overwhelming and the pace of course was organized well

weakness - lectures were not the most engaging

Strengths: Sections were very well organized and structured in a way that fostered understanding and comprehension of lecture material. Modules and presentations were well-organized. The course provided a good overview of key concepts and challenged class participants to apply them themselves.

This course was very nice in that the sections provided greater engagement opportunities and review opportunities. The guest lectures were also very interesting and engaging. However, the regular lectures themselves were a bit boring in that they went over the exact same things that the readings did.
Give grades back in a timely manner??
Section leader was excellent. Lectures presented the information in an easy to understand way, and assessments were creative, engaging, and approachable. The final was extremely scary.

strengths: interesting reading material
weaknesses: not super engaging lectures, assignments could be a little confusing, material seemed very surface level

The course is inherently interesting and covers a breadth of topics without feeling too superficial in any one topic. The course did, however, often rely too heavily on the readings and this made the lectures feel far less insightful once those readings were completed. I wish the lectures would lay on additional details or applications outside of the readings.
The class is kind of boring but not super hard which is nice

This course is very well organized, and I was thankful to have a class this semester that followed the dates strictly planned in the original syllabus. Ana de la O gives informative lectures that match with the readings, and I really enjoyed the discussion sections paired with each week. The only improvement I would say is to swap the final long-answer paper with the final short-answer paper. I think I would have done better on the long response had it been earlier in the semester, rather than the last week of classes. Maybe the short-response should be the final assignment before the final, not the long one. That last week is very difficult, and I know I could have done better work earlier in the semester.
The lectures felt a little repetitive, because we would often repeat slides that we had already gone over the past week.

Strengths: interesting readings
Weaknesses: lectures were extremely unengaging and rarely even touched on the readings; the course was unstructured and disorganized; the assignments were often unclear with confusing prompts, and the emphasis of the class seemed to be on memorizing jargon from the field rather than actually learning to think deeply.

Lecture was not very engaging and I felt as though I learned course material better on my own. Assignments were overly complicated and graded harshly. Little to no feedback was given. I felt as though grading was completely subjective. Assignments also took several weeks to be graded. For most of the semester we were a week behind on content. Lecture was much more confusing than it had to be. Course readings other than the textbook were not applicable to content and biased.

I loved writing the essays and learning via research so much more than the class itself, lectures, and discussion sections. The lectures were, in my opinion, very unengaging and discussion sections so depend on who your TA is. But the overall format of work for the course was excellent.
This course's lectures are very clear-cut, and there is ample direction and support for assignments.
The teaching is great but the power points are relatively brief.

The course was too easy too maintain the student's interest. I believe it would benefit from combining an introduction level with a continuation level of the material e.g like Econ 115 to keep the students more interested and engaged.

Readings always ended up being ahead of lectures because we were so behind with the slides in class. We would fully be two weeks behind in lecture and still going at normal pace in section. Professor de la o spent too long on unnecessary topics and skipped over others that felt important and necessary for assigments.
More analysis of class materials rather than direct notes.
No weaknesses!! Solid Class.

Strengths: Professor De La O is an incredibly experienced academic and I would encourage students to go to her office hours as she has so much knowledge to share. She is incredibly approachable and is very clearly student driven. I also appreciate how she discussed various countries and cultures throughout the course. Weakness: None.

Strengths: The weekly readings were pretty doable and reasonable. The flow of topics that we covered made logical sense and different concepts built on each other. The real-world examples of some of the concepts we were covering (eg. ethnic brokerage in Bolivia) were interesting and engaging. There's no midterm or in-person final exam which made for a more manageable workload.

Weaknesses: I had a hard time staying engaged with the course material besides the few times we covered real-world case studies. This could just be because I don't have an innate interest in abstract political concepts, like state formation, commitment issues, and typologies of regimes, but I found these topics to be less than engaging. While the lack of sit-down exams was appreciated, it felt like papers and reflection pieces snuck up on us pretty frequently. I think an increase in case studies, particularly from a more variable set of countries, would make the course feel less repetitive.
I think that the lectures could have been more engaging.

Strengths: Comprehensive, covered many topics
Weaknesses: Writing Prompts and discussions felt a bit randomly ordered

The course is well-structured with its set of modules. Furthermore, it does a good job of going through a variety of topics without getting too detailed and without taking a passing glance; it strikes a good balance for an intro political science course. The readings were interesting, and the writing assignments were well-spaced to allow for balance and focusing on certain important topics.

The material is the primary strength. The quality and clarity of instruction is lacking. I think that attendance at lecture shouldn't be required if the lecture will be so similar. Also the assignments should be better suited to reviewing the entire information.

The course is well-structured, and its readings are far more diverse than the conventional article-only readings common to political science courses (PLSC 116 opts for a combination of scholarly articles, textbook chapters, newspaper articles, podcasts, films, etc.). These qualities made for an incredibly engaging learning experience. Professor De La O clearly knew what she was talking about, and I was incredibly lucky to be able to learn from her. I also loved the weekly discussion sections and the fact that we got to engage with the readings during those sections, lectures, in weekly discussion question posts, as well as through our written assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only if you have to take it for your major. Otherwise I don't see the point.
yes.

Kind of a poli-sci gut. It is a great course with interesting content and simple assessments. However, it is not the most engaging. Take it if you have an interest in politics, specifically in democracy and elections.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student interesting in an introductory political science course focused on comparative politics. It did not really require background knowledge, which was helpful. I also enjoyed how many different topics we covered.
I would, especially if they are pursuing EP&E. The course is manageable and on the easier side, but there is still a lot to be gained if one wants to put in the effort.
Absolutely! Great intro course for internationals.

i would definitely recommend this class to others because it provides a great introduction into the understanding of political systems. the class doesnt require a huge workload, and is organized fairly well.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student who wants a good survey course on comparative politics, but not to students who are already engaged in political science, global affairs, or government because it might be a bit elementary.
Yes, it's a good introduction to comparative politics.
Yes, it is an easy to learn political science course.
Yes. It was approachable, easy to understand, and valuable.
it is not too bad - i think there are other classes at yale that can be more comprehensive. im aware this is an intro course but it was very surface level on topics that were core to the class.

I would recommend this course to another student, especially in combination with another global political science course like international relations. This course fleshes out the work political scientists do internationally and the kinds of questions or discoveries that have been made in this field.
Not particularly. Its an alright class thats not too hard but there are probably more interesting easy classes to take

Yes, this course was informative and had clear expectations. I always learn better when I know what is expected of me. The professor and all of the section leaders were very helpful with any questions about the course. I really recommend this course, especially if you are unsure which Intro Political Science course you should take.Take this one!
Yes, if you are a polisci major and need it for a requirement. If not, I think there are more interesting polisci classes.
Yes

No. The syllabus looks interesting at first but the lectures are very unengaging and rarely touch on the readings and the questions that the syllabus claims to explore. There was a constant focus on learning long, seemingly empty terms that were not even clearly defined in lecture, but that we were supposed to use to make judgments about the world. Very disappointing class.
No, I don't think I learned much and found myself to be very frustrated with assignments and confused after lecture.
Yes, definitely to get your PLSC intro credit (or EP&E). Super great beginner level course to learn about comparative politics and that you can use in other areas of political science later.
Yes, I would recommend this to students who need to fulfill the introductory course requirement of the PLSC major and are looking for a class that is comparative, multidisciplinary, and foundational.
Yes, I think it was a great introduction it comparative politics.
Not engaging but if you need it as a major distributional take it, the workload isn't too bad
Its a necessary PLSC intro course, I just may take it with another professor.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in politics or the world as a whole. This course is such an amazing tool in understanding how different nations function and provides a great deal of insight onto the people of those nations in the process, which is amazing.
Absolutely! Solid Class. 2 papers, 3 reflection pieces, and a take home final.

Absolutely! As someone who was never exposed to comparative politics, I thoroughly enjoyed this course! Since it is a survey course some topics are going to be more boring than others, but overall I enjoyed the readings. The assignments were also very innovative and weren't your basic research paper. You can obviously tell she cares about the learning process! The applications of Comparative Politics are also so expansive that any student would benefit from this course!

As a Political Science major that needed an introductory course, this was a fair option. However, I wouldn't take this course otherwise unless you are genuinely interested in basic political science and comparative politics concepts that at times feel pretty abstract and difficult to follow.
I would recommend this course to another student. I think that it is a great introduction into political science.
Yes I developed broad understanding of various political concepts.

I recommend Comparative Politics to another student, whether for a political science major or someone interested in comparative politics in general, for multiple reasons. The concepts and ideas discussed are fascinating, and Professor de la O and the teaching fellows are able to explain them in ways that are engaging. The workload is absolutely manageable.
Not particularly.
The course is a great introduction to the field of comparative politics. I highly recommend taking it!
